entry.title: Bioinformatic processing of microbiome (16s rRNA gene) sequencing data - QIIME 2 (2017.8)

link.title: Bioinformatic processing of microbiome (16s rRNA gene) sequencing data - QIIME 2 (2017.8)

entry.content:
QIIME 2 (2017.8) is a powerful, and community developed, microbiome analysis package that enables researchers to start an analysis with raw 16s rRNA sequence data. Data produced by QIIME 2 exist as QIIME 2 artifacts. A QIIME 2 artifact typically has the .qza file extension when output data stored in a file. Visualizations are another type of data (.qzv file) generated by QIIME 2, which can be viewed using a web interface https://view.qiime2.org (at Firefox web browser) without requiring a QIIME installation. Since QIIME 2 works with artifacts instead of data files (e.g. FASTA files), we must create a QIIME 2 artifact by importing our fastq.gz data files.

To find the PHRED offset used for the positional quality scores, execute the following script (BitBucket).

sh fastq_manifest_phred.sh

#!/bin/sh
# fastq_manifest_phred.sh
# checks-fastq-quality-score-format
FASTQ_FILE=$HOME/path/to/fastq.gz
zcat ${FASTQ_FILE} \
	| awk 'NR%4==0 {printf $0}' \
	| tr -d '\n' \
	| hexdump -v -e'/1 "%u\n"' \
	| head -n100000 \
	| sort -u

To import FASTQ files as QIIME 2 artifact and plot sequence positional quality scores, download the script from BitBucket and execute at SGE cluster as

qsub qiime2.2017.7_step1.sh

To denoise-paired sequence data and filter chimeras, QIIME 2 uses DADA2, which is an open-source software package that denoises and removes sequencing errors from Illumina amplicon sequence data, download the script from BitBucket.

qsub qiime2.2017.7_step2.sh

For feature filtering (i.e., removal of samples and features from a feature table) followed by alpha and beta diversity analysis and, taxonomic analysis, download the script from BitBucket.

qsub qiime2.2017.8_step3.sh

The above analysis also produce a key summary table or BIOM (Biological Observation Matrix) file containing feature (Operational Taxonomic Units, OTUs) abundance information across samples, along with various annotations and sample metadata. Alternatively, upload BIOM file to MicrobiomeAnalyst, a web-based tool for comprehensive statistical, visual and meta-analysis of microbiome data, for taxonomic profiling - to characterize community compositions based on methods developed in ecology such as alpha-diversity (within-sample diversity) or beta-diversity (between-sample diversity) and comparative analysis - to identify features that are significantly different among conditions under study.

After analyzing your data, it’s finally time to interpret your results!
entry.summary: QIIME 2 (2017.8) is a powerful, and community developed, microbiome analysis package that enables researchers to start an analysis with raw 16s rRNA sequence data. Data produced by QIIME 2 exist as QIIME 2 artifacts. A QIIME 2 artifact typically has the .qza file extension when output data stored in a file. Visualizations are another type of data (.qzv file) generated by QIIME 2, which can be viewed using a web interface https://view.qiime2.org (at Firefox web browser) without requiring a QIIME installation. Since QIIME 2 works with artifacts instead of data files (e.g. FASTA files), we must create a QIIME 2 artifact by importing our fastq.gz data files.

entry.title: A comprehensive map of the human complement system

link.title: A comprehensive map of the human complement system

entry.content: The human complement activation takes place through one or more of the well-established pathways (alternative, classical, and lectin) consisting of plasma and membrane-bound proteins. All three pathways converge at the level of C3 and are controlled by regulators. The entire network is considered as a simple recognition and elimination system of host immune-complexes and apoptotic cells and pathogens, and therefore promotes host immune homeostasis. We created this network of the human complement system under the umbrella of the UCSD Signaling Gateway project. For more details …

The entire network is considered as a simple recognition and elimination system of host immune-complexes and apoptotic cells and pathogens, and therefore promotes host immune homeostasis. We created this network of the human complement system under the umbrella of the UCSD Signaling Gateway project. For more details …

entry.title: Copy number variation (CNV) discovery next-generation sequencing (NGS) data.

link.title: Copy number variation (CNV) discovery next-generation sequencing (NGS) data.

entry.content:
CNVs represent gain or loss of genomic regions. CNVs transmit from parents to offspring or arise de novo and play important role in neuro-psychiatric disorders and cancers. Traditionally CNVs are identified through array based approaches but recent advances in genomic technologies, whole genome sequencing (WGS) approaches are becaming popular. Existing NGS-based approaches, which detect CNVs for individual sample level, usually yield low-detection accuracy, while joint modeling approaches use maximum advantage of Mendelian transmission within the parent-offspring trio improved CNV detection accuracy. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) data analysis pipelines for CNV discovery are available at Bitbucket | BWA MEM | CNAVnator | Pindel | SVseq2 | TrioCNV |

Figure. Distribution of the average read depth (RD) signal difference for neighboring segments on human Chr 12 (Chr12:758001-765000).
entry.summary: CNVs represent gain or loss of genomic regions. CNVs transmit from parents to offspring or arise de novo and play important role in neuro-psychiatric disorders and cancers. Traditionally CNVs are identified through array based approaches but recent advances in genomic technologies, whole genome sequencing (WGS) approaches are becaming popular. Existing NGS-based approaches, which detect CNVs for individual sample level, usually yield low-detection accuracy, while joint modeling approaches use maximum advantage of Mendelian transmission within the parent-offspring trio improved CNV detection accuracy. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) data analysis pipelines for CNV discovery are available at Bitbucket | BWA MEM | CNAVnator | Pindel | SVseq2 | TrioCNV |
